author: ben_a_adams
content: It does as you only pay for account warming once

author: big_tech_sux
content: True, i meant the sstore itself though

author: ben_a_adams
content: sstore price is more about bloating state than storage trie though?

author: barnabasbusa
content: Could we get all previous fork ids?

author: lightclient
content: the current fork id contains all previous fork ids

author: gtrintinalia
content: do we want every future fork that is schedule? Thinking about BPOs. The currently format only allows for the next schedule fork. Should we return a list of scheduled forks?

author: raulvk
content: i'm a bit concerned that [this EngineAPI::getBlobs change](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/671) is a functional no-op now. I think all EL teams are deferring adding partial blob responses, so we're just postponing extra coordination effort to the future to make it happen. Would it not be better to just implement it now and forget about it, putting it behind a request flag to avoid serde costs while unused, [as originally proposed](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/669)? That way the CL can begin using without additional coordination / releases needed from EL clients

author: siladu
content:
Between BPOs, will forkIds be the only calculated difference that you couldn't get from comparing genesis configs? 
Not sure the full eth_config response will add much value there so a lot of useless output if we list them all.

What about parameterising the currentFork? e.g. eth_config(BPO2) to see current=BPO2, next=BPO3

author: gtrintinalia
content: or even simpler,  instead of "next" we could return "lastest" scheduled fork, then forkId would account for all the previous forkIds

author: siladu
content:
Yeh I like latest. Think it should be in addition to next though, so `current, next, latest`. It's still valuable to know next IMO.

I think eth_config(timestamp) might be a better approach than eth_config(forkName) if we want to parameterise (or support both).
